title: How to Dig for Fossils and Gemstones

steps.headline: Know where to go to dig for treasure.
steps.description: The United States, for example, is rich in natural resources, but you need to find a place where its permissible to dig.

steps.headline: Contact your area's department of parks, outdoors, nature or recreation.
steps.description: (It should be called something like this. Try a Google search.) They may be able to point you to resources.

steps.headline: Get a permit to dig, but understand you will need to pay for it.
steps.description: In other cases, you may need to pay for what you take (charge is usually by the pound, but it's much cheaper than buying the same stones in a shop! ).

steps.headline: Research your home area's geology, or the geology of the area where you plan to dig.
steps.description: Know what kind of stuff you are looking for. The more you know, the better your chances of finding something good. Knowing how to date fossils may come in handy after you find some!

steps.headline: Some things to look for, depending on where you live: garnets, sapphires, agate, petrified wood, opal, diamonds, gold, silver, geodes, quartz, jasper, thunder eggs, fossils, soapstone, or arrowheads.
steps.description: (Yes, all these things can be found in various parts of America!)

steps.headline: Places where you can dig for interesting rocks are, naturally, mostly out in the middle of nowhere.
steps.description: Be prepared for a long drive and an all-day expedition, at least. Camping for a few days might be even better.

steps.headline: Know your alternatives to expensive prospecting tools.
steps.description: Prospecting tools are expensive. Rather than investing in a whole set for your first time out, you can rent them, or find a friend who digs as a hobby that you can borrow equipment from. Better yet, invite the hobbyist along and share your strength in exchange for their expertise! Rock and mineral shows are good places to meet people. Check for clubs in your area, too.
